Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 28 May 2022
Reviews.text:
Bought this as an Easter gift for my now 7 month old, it's easily one of her favourite toys over the past month. She loves watching it spin then taking the lid off and throwing the eggs around.
My 3.5 year old also loves it and it's a constant chore to get her to give it back to the baby. This can be solved by asking her to tidy it up which gives her just as much amusement as the baby has in taking it apart, and then she'll play peekaboo with her little sister with each of the dinosaurs.
It's survived two very energetic girls and their older cousins so it's definitely hardy enough to survive most kids.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 10 April 2022
Reviews.text:
Our little one immediately wanted to play with this so that was a good sign, anytime I take it and push it around it is instant fun time and they want to take over. It's a great little play toy, it's almost like a walker, but not stable or heavy enough (I guess), but once your little one can walk, it's a great way to encourage walking, but be careful because it has it's good and bad sides for not being a complete walker.
If the made some ort of addon to this to stabilize it, it could be a great walker plus a toy once they're done learning to walk. Other than that it's great and I recommend.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 16 April 2022
Reviews.text: Although the dinosaurs are cute and the structure is sturdy the fundamental flaw in this, is the fact that the dinosaur eggs simply don’t hatch! Even as an adult following the instructions all that happened was the dinosaur eggs turned on their sides, still not hatching! Frustrating for a young toddler and frankly, pointless.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 25 April 2022
Reviews.text: Purchased for my 2 year old who has additional needs and likes rotational schema . It's very versatile and can be played with in many ways.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 6 January 2022
Reviews.text:
Our baby loves this toy! It is just a shame that the item came with the packaging taped to the stickers meaning that when it was removed it damaged the item as well as leaving a sticky residue on the dome.
Other than that it's a great toy. The spin feature is easy to use, the eggs are colour coordinated and each dinosaur is unique.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 15 May 2022
Reviews.text:
Bought as an alternative Easter present. Lovely little toy, both my 1 year old and 3 year old enjoy playing with. However it arrived missing the top half of the egg, I had assumed it was in the packaging underneath but unfortunately not.
Was too late to send it back for a replacement before Easter and as my son's have other compatible eggs I decided to keep it. They still enjoy playing with it in spite of the missing piece (they generally just leave the dino egg in the little car) but I was a bit disappointed with Amazon's quality control checks.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 19 January 2022
Reviews.text:
Lovely smart dinosaur toy !
Finally a toy that picks up instead of creating mess 😆.
I have ordered this for my 23 months old son at that time.
He is a bit shorter for his age so he reaches well the handler of this toy,but older kids would have to bend it .
I have later noticed that the front part can come off the dinosaur so that younger kids can play with it too while crawling.
In this case I have my second son who is 7 months at the moment so he can use it too:)
The dinosaur body is made of a rubber type material ,so it doesn't feel as plasticky as other toys.
It picks up well the balls , it is intelligent and provides a lot of fun.
Nice one !

It is just the right height for a toddler and it is suitable for 1 year plus. It is a good fun toy but it doesn’t seem to be a favourite in our house.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in France on 25 January 2022
Reviews.text:
Voici un jouet-micro qui reprend une des chansons du dessin animé "TOUS EN SCENE 2".
POINTS POSITIFS :
- Effets lumineux façon boule à facettes
- Le son est clair et bien audible
- Simple d'utilisation
- Le bouton s'actionne facilement : pas besoin de forcer
- Possibilité de le brancher sur un MP3
- Changement de la voix possible
- Le micro se prend bien en main par sa forme
- Il peut facilement s'emmener "partout" avec ses 21cm de long
- Fonctionne avec 2 piles AAA incluses
- Le micro parait de bonne qualité
POINTS NEGATIFS :
- Une seule chanson disponible
- Cable de branchement (MP3) non inclus
- L'autocollant décoratif en façade se décolle un peu
- Attention : jeu bruyant :)
AU FINAL : Un jouet sympathique qui plaira aux petits fans du fameux dessin animé mais aussi à ceux qui aiment chanter ou faire semblant. Les possibilités de jeu restent limités mais tout en simplicité par contre pour votre enfant : ce micro est facile à utiliser et à prendre en main et ne nécessite pas forcément l'aide d'un adulte. Son prix est de 20€ mais je ne pense pas que cela vaille plus...

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in Germany on 2 January 2022
Reviews.text:
Gleich vorweg: Ich kaufte das Set eh nur wegen der Formen - und es stellte sich heraus, dass dem nicht ganz so ist.
Ich verwende Recycling Toilettenpapier, die Falten sind teils klar erkennbar und ich muss wesentlich mehr Papiermasse verwenden, wenn ich nicht hauchdünne "Lackierunterlagen" will.
Ich dachte mir, von Osterschmuck bis Katzenspielzeug wäre vieles drin.
Was ist nun die Erfahrung?
+ Es macht Spass.
+ Es wird je nach (Toiletten)Papier unterschiedliche Ergebnisse abwerfen.
+ Um ein ganzes Ei oder Herz zu basteln, muss man zwei Hälften aneinander kleben.
+ Es funktioniert sogar echt gut, aber die Pappmache Dinger (die mich frappierend an Eierkartons-Karton erinnern) muss man dann doch zur Gänze grundieren und erst dann bemalen.
+ Man kann sicherlich mit Materialmix experimentieren, Grundierungen wie Gips, Acryl, Seidenpapier usw. Die Papiermache-Masse kann man ja auch im Mixer machen, eventuell mit Toilettenpapier als Pressformen-Filter.
+ Die Klemmpresse ist eher was für junge Kinder. Sie hat kaum Kraft. Erwachsene, Jugendliche, usw werden eher mit den Fingern weiter kommen als mit dieser Klemmvorrichtung. Man könnte sicherlich auch Schraubzwingen verwenden, muss man aber nicht.
+ Das Plastik ist relativ gute Qualität. siehe vorherige Zeile ;-)
+ Schade finde auch ich, dass nur zwei Formen beiliegen und keine Erweiterungen erhältlich sind. Vorstellbar ist, dass man mit anderen Bastelhilfen oder Kochformen weitere nette Dinge basteln kann.
+ Mein Fazit war: Ich kaufte auch die Idee! Ich wäre nie von selbst draufgekommen..
--> Letztendlich ein wunderbares Spielzeug und eine Bastelidee, die es in sich hat!

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in Germany on 9 September 2021
Reviews.text:
Wer kennt es nicht von früher? Mit Zeitungspapier, Klopapier und Kleister lustige Figuren herstellen und bemalen.
Das Tomy Mache Magic Set verspricht schnelle Erfolge mit wenig Aufwand. Also alles ausgepackt und losgelegt.
Dabei sind sehr viele Sticker, zwei Glitzergelstifte, negativ-Formen, die Presse, ein Auffangbehälter für Wasser, ein Löffel zum Befüllen von Wasser und eine Anleitung.
Man braucht nur noch ca 1,2 Meter Klopapier und Wasser. Schon kann es losgehen.
Das Klopapier wird in kleine Fetzen zerissen. Je kleiner, desto besser das Ergebnis. Nun legt man die Fetzen in die ausgewählte Form. Bei uns war es das Ei. Die Fetzen werden so ausgelegt, dass sie das komplette Innere des Eis bedecken. Nun füllt man mit dem Löffel etwas Wasser ein. Das Papier saugt sich nun langsam voll und legt sich eng an die Innenwand der Form an. Nun legt man weiter Fetzen auf die nasse Schicht. Ganz nach alter Pappmache Gewohnheit.
Ist das Paper verbraucht, nimmt man die Gegenseite des Eis und drückt sie in die Negativform. Dieser "Klotz" wird nun auf den Auffangbehälter gestellt und in die Presse geschoben.
Nun heißt es drehen. Und zwar so lange, bis es zwei Mal klickt. Dann wieder Aufdrehen, Wasser aus dem Auffangbehälter schütten und das ganze Spiel von vorn. So lange, bis kein Wasser mehr im Auffangbehälter landet.
Danach die Form vorsichtig rausnehmen, öffnen und das gepresste Pappmache-Ei herausnehmen.
Wir gaben es dann 24 Stunden auf der Heizung trocken lassen und bemalt.
Ich finde dieses Set toll weil man keinen Kleber braucht. Flecken von Druckerschwärze durch die Zeitung gibt es nicht. Man halt alles zum basteln zu Hause und es geht sehr einfach.
Das einzig negative finde ich, ist dass es keine weiteren Formen gibt. Man kann nur Eier und Herzen machen. Ich hätte so gerne Erweiterungssets gekauft.
Ansonsten kann ich es nur empfehlen, gerade für kleine Kinder. Macht super viel Spaß.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in France on 12 September 2021
Reviews.text:
Machine pour fabriquer des petits galets en papier Maché.
En fait il suffira d’humidifier du papier toilette et de le compresser grâce a la machine, à l’aide de moules deux sont compris avec celle-ci un en forme d’œuf un en forme de cœur.
Vous pourrez ainsi décorer les formes comme bon vous semble avec de la peinture, des paillettes, des autocollants peux importe du moment que l’on laisse parler la créativité.
Du coup c’est sure que cela reviendra moins cher le papier toilette a un coût vraiment bas et cela permet des réalisations assez sympa.
Le coffret est prévu pour les enfants à partir de six ans c’est une activité qu’il veut faire seul à partir de cet âge là il suffit de bien leur expliquer et on peut rarement se tromper.
Cela permet de faire une activité manuelle le mercredi après-midi ou pendant les vacances au lieu que les enfants soit sur les tablettes ou devant les écrans.
Bon rapport qualité prix pour cette machine j’espère que d’autres moules ser ajouter par la suite afin de varier les formes.

a guessing game that you chat with. It has a lot of quite unusual things within the topics as well, Biathlonbeing one such example in the sports one.
After inserting the 3 AAA batteries (yep 3 of them) he was ready to go. Just push his nose and he starts talking. He explains all the rules and starts asking questions, just like 20 Questions. You think of an animal and then answer Yes or No questions. Eventually Magic Jinn asks if “XXX” is the animal your thinking of. We did stump Magic Jinn but he also did get the animal eventually. I think some of the answers could go either way, like he asked “Is he a Primate?” or “Do he have black hair?” Well those questions could go either way for the animals we were thinking of.
My kids had fun and they had to do some thinking on their end to answer Magic Jinn’s questions. It is great to get kids thinking and working together!

Very clever, and quite absorbing.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 13 September 2021
Reviews.text:
My daughter has recently become a fan of all things Friends having watched the series (all of them) approximately have a dozen times now. A trivia quiz, particularly one which is as interactive as this one seemed like an ideal idea. What this has proved to me however is that despite thinking I was a friends fan, (or at least I used to be around 25 years ago) I am not. I really struggled to answer a lot of these questions although I did have fun playing the game. My daughter, however, really enjoyed it and did particularly well.
I do like the nostalgia aspect of this game, the fact that the game itself is in the shape of a VHS is a really cool idea (I think I owned the first 6 or 7 seasons on VHS way back in the day!). It’s a really good throw back to a classic comedy series which was a staple of my generations growing up.
The one thing I would say is that the impromptu challenges that the game throws at you are maybe more appropriate in certain circles, maybe a group of good friends rather than as a family game.

Reviews.text: I liked playing this on my own but you could play with someone and battle it out. So it basically is a series of true and false questions. I wish they did a Harry Potter version. It is not very loud so you have to listen carefully. It is very simple to play with and comes with batteries. Something to pass the time and is shaped like a VHS tape so shove it on your shelf with your friends collection.

Reviews.text: One of our most played games. Everyone loves this one. No complicated instructions - the game explains them to you! Totally age inclusive. Once the game starts we forget we are playing against an 8 year old or 80 year old, we’re all listening to the question master and want to hit our buzzer first! Fun, competitive easy to play game and it has some twists that can peg back a run away leader, making it fair for all. Always lots of laughter when playing this game. One round of this game is not enough, be prepared for the shouts of “again! again!”

Reviews.text: Our 1 year old loves this toy!

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 13 September 2019
Reviews.text:
My two year old daughter is very rough with toys, so it is a good job this is well made and very sturdy! Basically you give your toddler the spoon and they batter the egg with it. It also has an interactive button on the front! It wobbles like a Weeble (remember them?) and plays tunes that will clearly grind your gears in a matter of no time.
But all in all the daughter loves it, it's eyes light up red and green like a mad 'un too!
So get ready and bash it's head in along to the beat of Twinkle Twinkle!
I would recommend this for ages from approx. 6 months to 4 years, as it is a decent interactive toy.
If you found this review useful then please click the helpful button below, and be sure to check out our other reviews of products you may also consider purchasing from Amazon. Thank you :-)

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 10 September 2019
Reviews.text:
This toy is very interesting for little ones as it creates various sounds and tunes, and the eyes light up as well. The tapping part is not suitable for babies as they would need to hold the spoon and hit the toy with a decent amount of force, that is why on the packaging it says 18+ months. The only mode that would be interesting for the younger babies is the one where it plays the song by itself.
The egg is 12 cm tall and 10 cm wide so it is safe to use around babies, however, the spoon could be a choking hazard. The battery compartment is safely secured with screws on the underside and the toy comes with batteries included, neat.
It is made out of sturdy plastic and is overall quality made.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 25 September 2019
Reviews.text:
This is a very cute toy suitable for little ones aged 18 months and older purely I suspect because of the spoon and the force needed to hit the egg. There is just a music setting which would be perfectly suitable for a younger one with adult supervision as the music is quite nice and the eyes light up on the chick.
The chick arrives in demo mode which is really loud but when you change it to on the volume does decrease a bit.
There are 4 different modes; the music playing I mentioned above, funny sounds (chick noises, boing noises etc), a do-re-mi one where your little one taps the top of the egg to copy the chick and another mode which I feel is similar to the do-re-mi one in all honesty yet is called musical layer.
The chicks eyes light up when it is being tapped or when it is playing the music or silly sound effects and its a nice little toy albeit with limited play value.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 7 September 2019
Reviews.text:
Playing with this toy is a bit like a mini disco experience for toddlers; it plays classic kiddie tunes but with a really funky dance beat while the glasses light up red and green like disco lights. It's quite loud even on the normal mode so is designed to be danced to, its not like a typical noisy toy that plays away passively in the background.
As for the toy itself it's fairly limited in what it does; you tap the top with a spoon and it plays music in sync. My 3 year old finds it a fun addition to when we do music time, I keep it in the box with her maracas, drum, tambourine etc and we play with it when making music but it doesn't really have a huge amount of play value beyond that.
This would make a good gift for toddlers that love making music, but it's quite loud and may bother others that don't like loud noises.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 7 September 2019
Reviews.text:
My grandchildren have all loved the "Hide & Squeak" eggs so I had high hopes for this. The hide and squeak eggs are small and easy for little hands to hold and also help co-ordination as they fit the two halves of each egg together.
This requires a lot less input from the child and while it will play different tunes as you tap the shell with the spoon or whatever the child finds to hit it with, that is about it. It is cause and effect but that is about all. The child will hopefully learn the songs but I do feel that the enjoyment is somewhat passive and th child will quickly lose interest.
It is a good sturdy toy that is well balanced and will not break easily with being dropped or pushed around by the child but I do feel that the appeal is a bit limited.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 29 August 2019
Reviews.text: My daughter has the toomies eggs in the egg box already so this made a nice addition for her. When we received it, it was going off in the box which made the postman laugh! It is a funky looking egg with a few nice features, the sunglasses light up in different colours either side, as well as lots of sounds and tunes. It comes with a spoon which the child can bash the egg with. This was great fun for my daughter but I think it will be a short lived toy, in actual fact the original toomies are better for concentration and actual play time. Comes in a nice box and would make a perfect Easter present instead of a chocolate egg. Marking down one star as it could do with just a couple more features.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 13 September 2019
Reviews.text:
3.5 Stars
This is quite simple and easy to use, especially for a growing young child. I said yes to this for my daughter because I thought that would be perfect for her. She enjoyed playing with it for a while, even if I found the constant noise just a ‘little’ frustrating, but she got a little bored of it after a short while.
The button at the front controls the mode, which then controls the songs and effects that’s made when you tap the shell with the spoon. It’s a little starter musical egg-strament that’s fun and exciting for children and it’s good that it lights up and grabs their attention even more so.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 23 September 2019
Reviews.text:
I grew up with Tomy and it has always been a brand I associate with quality. All these years later it is nice to see that the cost/quality ratio has not slipped.
This little egg is great fun. Kids LOVE making noise and given half the chance love to whack things, in the past, I have reverted to giving the little guy a wooden spoon and a saucepan, but it's nice to be able to give a purpose-made toy :)
The egg is very sturdy, colourful and great fun for little ones to hit with the spoon. Batteries are included (which is nice) and includes 4 modes to keep the little ones busy. For the price, a great item.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 31 August 2019
Reviews.text:
We received the Tomy toomies beat it egg today and our 9 month old was all over it although it’s going in the bedroom as it is going to be his Easter present. The toy was set on Demo setting which was really loud, too loud! So I changed it to on mode and it seems quieter but still on the loud-ish side.
The toy looks really cute and our boy was fascinated by its eyes as they lighten up. He hasn’t played with the spoon as he is quite young for that but he pressed the button on the front quite a few times and loved the different sounds that came from the toy.
The toy comes include batteries.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 23 September 2019
Reviews.text:
Another fun TOMY toy - a large version of the 'veggies' in the box - this one has lights, sounds and interactivity.
My son enjoys giving it a good old bash with the spoon and delights in the resulting entertainment from the lights or the sounds - it's the sort of toy for your little one to explore either alone 'by accident' or with an adult showing how each part works. Either way, as I say, it is great fun.
Not too big either, and so it gets carried along with us too.
Recommended

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 28 November 2019
Reviews.text: Perfect little toy for a toddler. Tap the egg with the spoon and it wobbles, makes sounds and generally gets the children laughing. There’s also little games they can play as they get older - for example - copying a sequence. With these Little games I feel this will be a toy that will be played with for a very long time

I, and importantly my daughter really like this.
Really funky its a good size, well made and comes preinstalled with batteries.
The tune is really funky and here's one in particular that triggers memories of the old Red Dwarf theme tune.
Fun for now

toy.name: TOMY T20064A Zoom Action Figure Set, Wheeling, Playset with Steel Awesome, Ricky and Loop Hoopla, Free Standing Kids Motorbike Toys for Boys and Girls 3 Year +, Multi
Toomies E73264 Bubble & Bake Bathtime, Baby, Bath Toddlers, Kitchen Themed Bubble Making Toy, 2 in 1 Set, Kids Water Play Suitable for 18M & 2 3 & 4 Year Old Boys & Girls, Multicoloured

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 28 September 2021
Reviews.text: Was really looking forward to using this with my daughter but as you can see from the picture it constantly slips down from its own weight! This might be better on tiles but as mine are ridged I have to use it on the bath tub side and well two suction cups doesn’t cut it. I have decided to keep it cause at the end of the day kids don’t care, but my ocd and product satisfaction has took a bullet.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 4 April 2022
Reviews.text:
The suction Cups are a bit of a mare. They randomly fail and cause the toy to clunk into the bath- which isn't a problem unless you're watching a horror movie while the kids are in bed and suddenly think a burglar is upstairs demolishing the bathroom.
The pie dish doesn't spin when the water hits it, unless you give it a bit of a push to start it off.
The sink part does work when it is pushed down, the only negative being that the suction cups are so plop, that one push sends it falling off the tiles.
The little pan is easy to use and the tiny scoop is a great way to encourage kids to use utensils.
My son loves it but doesn't play with it as it was intended. He tries to cook his bath ducks in it and fills the sink with all of my shampoo.
It is a cute little set but it really needs better suction cups for the tiling and could do with more water cascades as the ones on the oven for not very impressive no matter how much water you chuck on it.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 15 October 2021
Reviews.text: My kids were really excited to play with this, ran the bath, but for some reason the kitchen wouldn't stick to the tiles or bath, it kept sliding down. I went to try it the next day and it was stuck perfectly to the tiles. Maybe its a moisture thing and was better once the walls and bath had dried (they weren't particularly wet to start with). All good though, still played with after a week of daily baths.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 25 October 2021
Reviews.text: Does not stick to the side of the Bath as it’s too heavy - waste of time but the kids do love it

However it is no suction power whatsoever ever, so you can’t play with it on the tiles/side of the bath, which is the point right? The toy is just far too heavy for the cups. I don’t regret buying it though as they enjoy playing with it, however I need a new toy for the bath haha

It doesn't function as it is supposed to at all.

The tap being able to pump also isn't very great and the 'bubble pan' was really difficult for her to achieve anything like the videos I've watched. Also the sink constantly leaks even though I put the setting on closed. I personally think that she could have got more for her money. However, it does look nice and she enjoyed filling it up.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 13 September 2021
Reviews.text:
First impressions were great, it came in a fairly large branded box which immediately caught my daughters eye and made her excited for her bath which is unheard of! It’s great to find a bath toy that’s different from all the others on the market, no ducks or boats in site! So the pros and cons on this for us were as follows:
Pros:
1. It’s brightly coloured and has lots to do on it
2. The “oven” door opens but they can also put their hand straight through it if they don’t want to bother.
3. The tap squirts out water
4. The saucepan is actually quite handy for hair washing!
5. It’s a well known/ trustworthy brand
Cons:
1. There’s two big suckers on the back to hold it to the bath but they didn’t work well enough so it constantly slipped down, especially when she tried to push the tap down it instantly fell down. In the end I had to put it on the wall tiles and let it sit on the side of the bath and let the water run down that way as it was the only way to get it to stay in position. This meant our daughter had to stand up to use it properly in the bath which meant we had to hold on to her the whole time to stop her slipping.
2. We couldn’t get it to make bubbles as directed, pushing the yellow button didn’t seem to do anything.
Overall I still think despite the cons this is a great bath toy, my little girl who’s nearly 3 loves it and doesn’t put up any fuss when I say it’s bath time now which is great and well worth the £20 just for that!

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 6 January 2022
Reviews.text:
The principle of this is quite nice. It is a set that really comprises of two toys, one is a working sink (with a tap) and the other a kitchen stove toy.
The sink is pretty much straightforward. It has a working plug that can stay open or closed. When the plug is closed, and there is water in the sink, the tap can be operated to pump the water and make it come out of the tap. This is quite clever and I quite enjoyed it myself! The operating of the tap does require some effort, so it could be difficult for smaller children and it could also be tricky depending on how high this has been stuck on the bath/wall, etc.
The kitchen stove is also quite ingenious in its concept. The pot has holes to use as a shower - I have with my daughter and she loves it! - but when placed on the hob carefully it then stops the water from escaping. Then the pushing of the big yellow button on the stove creates some ripples to the water, which if some bath gel is added to it, can imitate the effect of water boiling. There is also a pretend oven with a door and a cake dish that can be put in the oven. When the pot on the stove is turned a different way, then the water can flow through the holes and make the cake dish spin.
Overall, this set is big, colourful and captures the child's interest. However, a bid minus is the suction power of this set. I have found it very difficult to make it stay on the bathtub itself, the bath wall, etc. Also, I don't know why they have used only two suckers rather than 4, which I would have thought would make more sense!
Overall, a decent toy, let down by the suction power. However, if you, like me, find a way around it, it can offer fun to the bathing child and can spend that extra bit longer in the bathtub relaxing an playing!

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 1 September 2021
Reviews.text:
I ordered this bath toy for my niece who has just turned 1 and she loves it! It is truly leading to so much bath time fun.
I have found that a lot of the bath toys on the market now either stop working after a few weeks or go mouldy quite quickly- this however does neither, which I’m thrilled with. It attaches to the wall on a tiled surface with great suction cups; no batteries are required so no risk of water hazards.
I would say this toy is more aimed at a girl rather than a boy because of the colour scheme, which I feel is a shame as toys really should be gender neutral.
However, it promotes great role play- it consists of a bath time kitchen where the sink bubbles naturally when pressing the tap down, the saucepan again bubbles when on ‘the hob’ and it also has a spinning pie dish! It comes with a ladder and a saucepan which hook onto the side of the oven- it really has thought about the small details.
It’s a great toy that keeps my niece entertained for ages!
An extra tiny detail- the saucepan also has holes at the bottom which filter through to the spinning head which make the pie dish spin!
A great bath toy that I’m really optimistic will last!
Priced at £20 feels reasonable for a role play toy which so much attention to detail and extras.
Overall we’ve been pleased with this and happy to recommend.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 30 December 2021
Reviews.text:
For this review you need to look at two items 1. The product itself and 2. The suction to the bath.
1. The product is high quality and the kids love it. It’s easy to learn and play with and a perfect bath toy. However it’s completely useless and unusable because of item 2
2. The suction cups are too small and have no strength. The item is too heavy for the two number cups. It needed 4 as a minimum and of better quality. The item slides down into the bath and is more of a submarine than a play toy.
I’m currently searching Amazon for larger stronger suction cups to remedy the poor cheap options Toomie provide. I may update if successful.
If I hadn’t taken it out of the box and thrown it away over Christmas I would be returning this toy as it doesn’t stick to the wall

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in France on 13 September 2021
Reviews.text:
Ce jouet pour le bain est vraiment bien fait et ravira tous les petits cuisiniers en herbe.
Pour commencer, l'enfant peut mettre de l'eau dans l'évier. Grâce à un système de pompe, il fait vraiment jaillir l'eau du robinet. Lorsqu'on a fini de s'amuser avec l'eau, on peut l'évacuer grâce à un système de bonde.
Le jouet vient avec une louche, un moule et une casserole. Le moule se place dans le four. La casserole se place sur le feu. La casserole a des trous. On peut la placer sur le feu de sorte à ce que les trous soient bouchés, afin que l'eau ne s'écoule pas. L'enfant peut appuyer sur un bouton pour faire des bulles, comme si l'eau était en train de bouiller. Ce n'est pas aussi impressionnant que l'image sur la page produit, mais ça fait quelques bulles et ça amuse les enfants. Si on place les trous de la casserole de sorte à ce qu'ils soient alignés avec les trous présents sur les "plaques de cuisson", l'eau s'écoule alors dans le moule qui est dans le four est celui-ci tourne sur lui-même. Mes enfants adorent.
J'apprécie aussi le fait que le jouet soit muni de crochets pour ranger et faire sécher les objets. De même, le système de ventouse fonctionne bien et les évacuations sont bien faites pour éviter la moisissure.
En espérant vous avoir été utile.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in Germany on 8 April 2022
Reviews.text:
Unsere zwei Kinder baden sehr gerne und haben sich mal wieder neues Badespielzeug gewünscht. Da kam dieses Produkt gerade recht.
Es macht den Kindern viel Spaß zu kochen und anschließend abzuwaschen.
Was ist toll:
+ für die Größe und den Preis viel zu bespielen
+ stabiler Kunststoff
+ bunte und kräftige Farben
+ individuelle Anbringung in jeder Badewanne durch Saugnäpfe
Was ist nicht so toll:
- Wenn bspw. das Waschbecken voll Wasser gefüllt wird rutscht dieses am Saugnapf nach unten ins Wasser. Gleiches gilt für den Backofen
An und für sich ist die Befestigung mit Saugnäpfen eine tolle Sache. Diese sind groß und halten auch ziemlich fest. Irgendwann rutschen sie aber trotzdem immer nach unten.
Eventuell wäre etwas zum festhaken am Badewannenrand besser gewesen.
Trotzdem lieben unsere Kinder es, zumindest so lange wie es über der Wasserkante bleibt.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in France on 11 September 2021
Reviews.text:
Voici une idée originale en ce qui concerne ce jouet pour le bain : votre enfant va pouvoir cuisiner tout en se lavant :)
POINTS POSITIFS :
- Pas besoin de piles.
- Vous pouvez jouer avec le four et l'évier en même temps ou séparément : c'est au choix, et vous avez ainsi
la possibilité d'occuper 2 enfants à chaque bout de la baignoire.
- Les éléments tiennent parfaitement bien en place sur la baignoire grâce à un système de ventouses.
- L'eau coule "pour de vrai" du robinet de l'évier.
- L'eau dans la casseroles se met à bouillir également pour de vrai (en faisant des bulles via un jeu de bain
moussant).
- Le plat à tarte tourne aussi "pour de vrai".
- Grâce aux crochets sur le coté du four, votre enfant pourra y suspendre le louche et la poêle : pratique !
- Ce jeu fourmille d'activités autour de l'eau et de la cuisine qui vont stimuler l'enfant tout en jouant.
- Grâce à ce jouet, l'enfant va pouvoir comprendre la relation de cause à effet.
- Le plastique utilisé pour ce jouet est de bonne qualité.
- Le jouet est très coloré , agréable visuellement parlant.
AU FINAL : Très beau jouet d'un point de vue qualitatif de la marque Tomy qui offre à votre enfant une nouvelle façon de jouer dans son bain. Tout fonctionne très bien, c'est orignal, amusant, costaud, bien fait... Le prix affiché à ce jour (25€) est tout de même une limite à ne pas dépasser selon moi.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in France on 13 September 2021

Sûrement pour les couleurs vives !!

Ou les supers accessoires qui poussent !!
Ou pour l originalité ??
Moi je dirais un mélange de tout ça .
Excellent jouet très bien conçu , qui fait jeu d éveil en même temps que jeu d imitation et jeu de motricité .
Un jouet de bain parfait , idéal à offrir , dans son grand carton .
Il est top !! Je recommande pour les bébés et les tous les enfants ! 🧼

toy.name: TOMY Ahoy There! Card Game, A Fast-Paced Family Card Game, Action Card Game for Boys and Girls, Card Board Games from 6, 7, 8, 9, Years and Up

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 6 November 2020
Reviews.text:
This game is advertised for 4+. I brought it to play with my 3 year old and we have had no issues with it. The only small parts that you may come across are little bits of plastic when you take the swords out of there plastic frame. (I have attached a photo of how they arrive)
This game is simple but it is just what I was after, a game the whole family can play. My three year old has had many hours fun playing with this as have I.
This game is also good to help encourage counting as after each game my little one counts how many swords it took that time. Each time is changes. Some times is can be just 1 and the next it could be 20.
It may seem a little pricey for what is it but I would recommend.
This would make a great Christmas or birthday gift.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 22 January 2021
Reviews.text:
Our two year old’s first game! I remember seeing this advert as a child and thought it’s a nice, simple, easy to play game without any swallowable little bits. The smallest parts here are the swords, which are safe, but, feel incredibly cheap and don’t really fill the holes / slits properly - you really have to jam them in hard, even then they look like they can fall out any minute...which isn’t great at all frankly. £10 might be a big ask, but it really should be better from Tomy.
The game itself is foolproof and fun, consisting of a barrel, afore mentioned cheap swords (4 different colours) and the eponymous pirate and that’s it! If nothing else, it’s an easy fun game for 10/15 minutes at a time and teaches your child the valuable lessons of sharing and waiting your turn. A pity those swords are so cheap!

Reviews.text:
.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 21 October 2020
Reviews.text:
In the hope of entertaining a very bored boy in yet another lock down period, I bought this to kill a few hours here or there. I had this as a child & seem to remember it being pretty funny.
The time it took opening the box & setting it up was far longer than how long this game was played with before it was put away. It’s cheaply made, the barrel is flimsy, the pirate either pops out in the 1st couple of swords or not at all. Because the barrel is so flimsy, you’ve got to hold it down in order to not knock it over when you put the swords in. Honestly, it’s a let down all in all. Waste of a tenner

Reviews.text: This is a fun little game. Easy game for all ages. The kids are always eager to see which sword will cause the pirate to pop up! Very engaging. Good fine motor practice, and the element of surprise keeps the kids at the game. Only downside is that sometimes the pirate never pops out because the little swords aren't put in correctly. Otherwise, a deservedly popular game which deserves 5 stars.

Pop up pirate.
I got this as a new game to play now the littlest is 3.5 years. It doesn't feel the most well made but it is put together ok. It is lightweight but I don't know how durable.
You put the swords all around the barrel, in their gaps and then one of them will trigger the pirate to pop up, which isn't far and hasn't yet hit anyone in the face, so that's good.
You need to push down and twist the pirate to reset. This is where I had issues. The piece that goes down likes to get stuck every now and again, leaving the kids with no winner and a boring game that only half the time works. This was disappointing to them, as they really liked trying to make him pop!
I wouldn't recommend this, I just don't feel like it will last long enough. It didn't even last 2 goes before the spring for jammed. Waste of money. I'd have said worth £5.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 6 August 2017
Reviews.text:
I got this game as my grandson finds it exciting waiting to see when the pirate pops up. The colours of the swords are nice and bright and as we use this while learning is speech therapy lessons, he gets to choose a colour of a sword and place it in the barrel.
This is worth the tenner I paid as it is a speech aid to make his learning fun, it helps him choose a colour and say the word and also to play the game with his cousins when they come over.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 21 February 2021
Reviews.text: I never played this game as a child but my daughter had it at school and loved it. Not sure if it’s just our version but the plastic is so cheap. You have to snap the daggers out of a plastic frame so you’re left with plastic nodules sticking out which can be sharp. About 50% of the time it doesn’t pop up. And loads of the daggers don’t stay in when you slot them in the sides. They just fall out again. And as for packing away. It doesn’t come with a box so it’s a real pain as the daggers just lie around next to the main barrel part so it’s messy for storage. Wish I’d not bothered getting it.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 9 August 2021
Reviews.text: Not a fun game at all because you will always know where to insert the sword within one minute of using the toy. The mechanism is so obvious and simple that the position for the pirate to pop is always the same if you fix it onto the pirate. Very boring. Also nowhere to store all the swords - that big barrel should be openable to double as storage for the little swords. Hard to press the pirate in for my almost four year old so the game always needs an adult to help insert it, and it’s just too predictable and therefore boring for the adult.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 16 October 2017
Reviews.text: This takes me back! I bought one of these for my eldest Son 30 years ago and the design hasn't changed a bit - I still have the original up in the loft, a bit faded but still working. Now that my Grandson is old enough, I have asked Santa to bring one of his very own. Can't wait to enjoy it with him at Christmas time. I have seen slightly cheaper alternatives in the shops, but wonder whether they will still be going strong 30 years later?!!

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 19 August 2017
Reviews.text:
As a child i remember playing pop up pirate. I think every person as a child either had popup pirate themselves or knew someone that did. It was one of the classic games that was fun but also had a degree of suspense to it. I purchased this for my young nephew for his birthday and he loved it, just as i loved it as a child as well. Him and his friends played with it on his birthday and were screaming with joy when the pirate popped out.
Quality of the item has not changes and works well, very good packaging and an outstanding price.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 27 May 2021
Reviews.text:
Really unhappy. Bought this for the kids when they come down, but when finally opened the package, the product doesn't work as advertised.
From the pictures, you can see that some of the sword don't stay stuck into the barrel (they're loose, whilst some swords do fit in perfectly). Secondly all the swords have been put into the barrell but the mechanism hasn't worked (the private is still stuck in the barrell).
I've been deceived by how great the product pictures look but wasted my money clearly.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 4 December 2016
Reviews.text:
I noticed this was down to a half decent price via Amazon's 'Cyber Deals Week' so decided to buy it to add to our Christmas retro game fest.
I'm no longer a child but do suffer from childish tendencies, so planning a retro games afternoon with the family over for this years festive break was a no brainer. As a child Pop-Up Pirate was one of my favourites along with a few other classics like Frustration, Twister, Operation and Guess Who.
I'm hoping to have them all in time for Christmas and starting with this bargain priced classic has given me a real buzz.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 4 May 2020
Reviews.text: Quality isn’t great but for £10 it will entertain my little one. The barrel is not on a stand and is easily knocked over when putting the swords into the barrel so I have to hold it the whole time. Even my children feel the need to hold the barrel as they know it will fall over causing some frustration! Pirate doesn’t always click into place and sometimes won’t pop by the end of the game so quality isn’t great! I remember the game being more sturdy when I had it as a child. For the price it’s ok,would return if more than £10. Encourages children to take it in turns to play!

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 6 November 2021
Reviews.text:
Used to love this Toy as a kid so I bought this for my autistic son but it brings more hassle than joy, the barrel the pirate sits in is very cheap and super light, the pirate seems ok but the swords don't stay in the holes so my son gets more frustrated with that than anything else.
I have tried to slightly bend the little grips on the swords but it makes no difference.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 22 July 2021
Reviews.text: Years ago my children had this game and we loved it. I bought this one to play with my granddaughter and though the concept is unchanged, this particular game is poor. It takes a lot to wrassle the pirate in place so that he stays down and then the first or second sword causes him to pop up again. It takes longer to re-set the pirate than it does to play the game; suspense is completely gone. Duff job.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 13 January 2021
Reviews.text: I bought this for my grandchildren at Christmas but was really disappointed with the quality. We've had this game at our After School Club for years and all the kids love it so I was really looking forward to playing it with my grandchildren. They loved it too but I don't think this new one will last 5 minutes. It's really poor quality in comparison.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 27 February 2021
Reviews.text: I mean we all know and love pop up pirate right? It was so nostalgic for me to be buying for my daughter. She’s 3, loves pushing the swords in, loves to be made jump when he pops. The slots that make him pop don’t seem to change though, so if they clue up to which one makes him pop then I imagine it wouldn’t be as fun. Works just fine for us though! I also appreciate something from my childhood that’s still exactly the same today.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 7 August 2021
Reviews.text:
This has been good fun for my 3/4 year-old. It's easy to play and is good for taking turns. The price was also reasonable (£8.28).
My only disappointment is that the daggers sometimes don't really stick in, they hang out a bit.
A very minor thing as well is that we were sent a French version with French text on the box. I prefer it when I'm sent the same product to the advert/listing.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 2 January 2022
Reviews.text: I bought this for us to play with at Christmas, mostly for my four year old granddaughter's benefit. It's perfect for playing with young children. It's quite a short game and my granddaughter is delighted with the 'cause and effect' element of it. Brightly coloured and well made. Good value for money.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 6 November 2020
Reviews.text:
This game is advertised for 4+. I brought it to play with my 3 year old and we have had no issues with it. The only small parts that you may come across are little bits of plastic when you take the swords out of there plastic frame. (I have attached a photo of how they arrive)
This game is simple but it is just what I was after, a game the whole family can play. My three year old has had many hours fun playing with this as have I.
This game is also good to help encourage counting as after each game my little one counts how many swords it took that time. Each time is changes. Some times is can be just 1 and the next it could be 20.
It may seem a little pricey for what is it but I would recommend.
This would make a great Christmas or birthday gift.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 22 January 2021
Reviews.text:
Our two year old’s first game! I remember seeing this advert as a child and thought it’s a nice, simple, easy to play game without any swallowable little bits. The smallest parts here are the swords, which are safe, but, feel incredibly cheap and don’t really fill the holes / slits properly - you really have to jam them in hard, even then they look like they can fall out any minute...which isn’t great at all frankly. £10 might be a big ask, but it really should be better from Tomy.
The game itself is foolproof and fun, consisting of a barrel, afore mentioned cheap swords (4 different colours) and the eponymous pirate and that’s it! If nothing else, it’s an easy fun game for 10/15 minutes at a time and teaches your child the valuable lessons of sharing and waiting your turn. A pity those swords are so cheap!

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 26 December 2015
Reviews.text:
.
Great game and a good one to get out if you have family or friends over as anyone can play and it will entertain all ages.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 21 October 2020
Reviews.text:
In the hope of entertaining a very bored boy in yet another lock down period, I bought this to kill a few hours here or there. I had this as a child & seem to remember it being pretty funny.
The time it took opening the box & setting it up was far longer than how long this game was played with before it was put away. It’s cheaply made, the barrel is flimsy, the pirate either pops out in the 1st couple of swords or not at all. Because the barrel is so flimsy, you’ve got to hold it down in order to not knock it over when you put the swords in. Honestly, it’s a let down all in all. Waste of a tenner

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 22 July 2019
Reviews.text: This is a fun little game. Easy game for all ages. The kids are always eager to see which sword will cause the pirate to pop up! Very engaging. Good fine motor practice, and the element of surprise keeps the kids at the game. Only downside is that sometimes the pirate never pops out because the little swords aren't put in correctly. Otherwise, a deservedly popular game which deserves 5 stars.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 3 June 2021
Reviews.text:
Pop up pirate.
I got this as a new game to play now the littlest is 3.5 years. It doesn't feel the most well made but it is put together ok. It is lightweight but I don't know how durable.
You put the swords all around the barrel, in their gaps and then one of them will trigger the pirate to pop up, which isn't far and hasn't yet hit anyone in the face, so that's good.
You need to push down and twist the pirate to reset. This is where I had issues. The piece that goes down likes to get stuck every now and again, leaving the kids with no winner and a boring game that only half the time works. This was disappointing to them, as they really liked trying to make him pop!
I wouldn't recommend this, I just don't feel like it will last long enough. It didn't even last 2 goes before the spring for jammed. Waste of money. I'd have said worth £5.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 6 August 2017
Reviews.text:
I got this game as my grandson finds it exciting waiting to see when the pirate pops up. The colours of the swords are nice and bright and as we use this while learning is speech therapy lessons, he gets to choose a colour of a sword and place it in the barrel.
This is worth the tenner I paid as it is a speech aid to make his learning fun, it helps him choose a colour and say the word and also to play the game with his cousins when they come over.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 21 February 2021
Reviews.text: I never played this game as a child but my daughter had it at school and loved it. Not sure if it’s just our version but the plastic is so cheap. You have to snap the daggers out of a plastic frame so you’re left with plastic nodules sticking out which can be sharp. About 50% of the time it doesn’t pop up. And loads of the daggers don’t stay in when you slot them in the sides. They just fall out again. And as for packing away. It doesn’t come with a box so it’s a real pain as the daggers just lie around next to the main barrel part so it’s messy for storage. Wish I’d not bothered getting it.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 9 August 2021
Reviews.text: Not a fun game at all because you will always know where to insert the sword within one minute of using the toy. The mechanism is so obvious and simple that the position for the pirate to pop is always the same if you fix it onto the pirate. Very boring. Also nowhere to store all the swords - that big barrel should be openable to double as storage for the little swords. Hard to press the pirate in for my almost four year old so the game always needs an adult to help insert it, and it’s just too predictable and therefore boring for the adult.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 16 October 2017
Reviews.text: This takes me back! I bought one of these for my eldest Son 30 years ago and the design hasn't changed a bit - I still have the original up in the loft, a bit faded but still working. Now that my Grandson is old enough, I have asked Santa to bring one of his very own. Can't wait to enjoy it with him at Christmas time. I have seen slightly cheaper alternatives in the shops, but wonder whether they will still be going strong 30 years later?!!

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 28 June 2020
Reviews.text: We all love this game, its a right good classic in most households. Very happy to report It's the same as I remember as a child, both my girls love it. It's a fun happy family game.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 2 January 2020
Reviews.text:
Fond memories playing this game as a child so purchased for my own kids this Xmas.
Sadly what arrived was very poor build quality and the 'pop' mechanism didn't work at all. Very disappointing - returned and refunded.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 14 February 2021
Reviews.text:
The daggers didn’t stay in they were all loose and slack. The pirate also didn’t pop up most of the time even when all daggers inserted. I requested a replacement which arrived quickly and did work just fine.
I also noticed that the 2nd one we got all items (barrel, pirate and daggers) were all wrapped in bags with the daggers on a snap off plastic frame. This hadn’t been the case with the first one suggesting it had already been opened, played with and identified as faulty.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 2 July 2022
Reviews.text: This game has provided much fun …. The shock of the pirate leaping out of the barrel - but also *counting back the swords into the box - *sorting into colours explaining how we make sure all is put away ready for the next time… really good value for money

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 8 January 2022
Reviews.text: The game is relatively easy to set up, however the pirate doesn't always click into place correctly so need an adult to fiddle about with it to get it to work again. Also, the pop up position doesn't vary at all, it's always in the same position which my two year old has already figured out. The initial couple of times we played it was fun, but not a long term game.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 7 January 2022
Reviews.text:
Nostagic game, enjoyed by all the family over Christmas. Only reason to not give 5 stars is that occasionally it didn't work! We'd add all the swords but the pirate didn't pop. Not the end of the world but worth noting as it happened a few times.
Otherwise lot of fun had with ages 3 to 60+

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 30 August 2021
Reviews.text: I used to love this game as a child and bought it after my son saw it on YouTube, most of the swords don't stay in (just fall straight back out) and now the push down bit that pops the pirate isn't coming back up, I've pushed a sword in every hole multiple times and it still won't release wish I didn't bother

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 31 August 2021
Reviews.text: We purchased this toy as our 2 year old grandson loves pirates (he readily watches a current children's tv programme about pirates) and we knew he could put the swords into the holes and enjoy it when the pirate popped out of the top. The toy is sturdy, it is an 'old time' favourite, it was well packaged and delivered on time.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 4 March 2021
Reviews.text: Bought for a 2 year old but no where near as good as the original all those years ago. Of the four colour of swords, only the blue and red ones work. The green and yellow swords are too thin and do not offer any resistance when placing in the slots, falling out as soon as you let go. Very disappointing if this is indeed an actual TOMY toy but having used it briefly, I suspect this is a cheap knock off. I don't recall TOMY products ever being under par and generally they were robust and functioned correctly. I'd suggest going to your local toy store to purchase this.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 20 June 2022
Reviews.text: Saw this classic toy and sent this to my cousins who are 6 and 8 as a gift. They think it's an absolute giggle and have had hours of fun with it. At a tenner it's a good price for something multiple kids can play with and keeps them busy for a bit

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 7 January 2014
Reviews.text:
NO BATTERIES NEEDED!!! So that means, yes, you take it out the box, remove it from the one bit of packaging, insert the swords and have fun straight away.
No hunting for mini phillips screwdrivers, do breaking teeth on twisted security cables...no mystifying instructions. Kids (3 and 6) enthralled and Daddy is quite happy too!
NOTE: If you are under 30 you will of course have no idea what I'm so happy about...in which case get back to your android device and communicating via ab'rv txt msg n takin selfies of ur piercings and reem tats. If you are over 30 and looking for a toy that brings nostalgia, familiarity and value for money as well as delight to your kids faces....this is the one!

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 19 May 2022
Reviews.text: It's a great game from my childhood but it only ever pops up when a sword is put it to either side of the pirate. Nowhere else. This makes it very predictable. However, as I can design in 3D and have a 3D printer I made a new base for the pirate that gives it 10 possible positions rather than the standard 2 positions. Now it's random and fun again!

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 9 November 2020
Reviews.text:
Often seen on the Korean game show "Running Man" its amazing how they can televise a whole game show around the pop up pirate game.
Just goes to show how fun this game can be.
Great for family gatherings and perfect for the kids.
When the pirate goes pop, it does give you a surprize :)
Great fun.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 28 February 2021
Reviews.text: Good game for my 2 year old. She loves pushing the swords in although they can be a bit finicky and look pushed in, even though they aren't! We have had the game 'stick'a few times too and have had to fiddle with it to get it working again. But on the whole, a reasonable price and a good game for small ones.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 3 September 2020
Reviews.text: The game it’s self is great my 3 year old son loves it. I’m giving it a 4 star because I am short of a sword which appears to be a manufacturing fault. I have emailed Tomy & is waiting for a response. It does effect the game if it’s the last hole that will pop & if all 4 colours are being used one player is short so hope to hear from Tomy soon

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 20 December 2020
Reviews.text:
Great game let down by a manufacturers defect.
On the green swords all the taps were too small which meant they had nothing to but on to inside the barrel.
I also remember the swords being much thicker on the older versions of the game, but this is much cheaper than they used to be back in the day

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 3 October 2015
Reviews.text:
Our little boy is only 27 months, but we wanted to try out family game/fun night. Since he is still little, I was trying to find a simple board/indoor game that we could all play. This fit the bill. He could understand the simple rules and easily manage pushing the swords in and out. The pirate doesn't jump out as high as I expected, but my son still thought it was hilarious.
We all had fun and have played this game quite a few times. I found it really reinforced the idea of taking turns. It did take us a while to teach him not to grab the pirate out of the barrel (at first he just wanted to play with him), but overall it was a good fit for his age/stage.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 4 January 2022
Reviews.text: This game is OK sometimes doesn’t want to work sometimes it does it’s a bit temperamental Feels really cheap Not sure why just doesn’t feel quite right it’s just doesn’t want to work properly with a very unsatisfied five-year-old at that

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 23 September 2021
Reviews.text: Far too light, it gets pushed over with putting the swords in. And often doesn't work, the pirate doesn't always jump out... pretty frustrating after 24 swords placed in... not worth the purchase.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 26 December 2020
Reviews.text: Bought early November for Christmas, gutted that all swords went in but the pirate didn't pop out until I wiggled some. Even then some swords just fall straight out like there too small to catch something and stay in. 3 year old enjoys playing it so will just have to put up with the poor quality.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 4 January 2020
Reviews.text: I had this when I was a kid, but this doesn’t seem anywhere near as good. On a number of occasions the pirate has popped with the first sword. On other occasions all swords have been inserted and it hasn’t popped. Not great when you’re trying to keep your kids entertained.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 12 August 2021
Reviews.text:
Bought as a christmas present and it looked like she had lots of fun!
This game can also be use to improve childrens listening skills, colour knowledge, patience and turn taking bu naming the colour sward that the child has to take out and vice versa the child names the colour u have to take out.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 20 March 2021
Reviews.text: Not great quality and cheaply made. Some of the swords won't stay in the slots so totally defeats the object of the game. Son has lost interest as it's more annoying than enjoyable.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 17 April 2017
Reviews.text:
Great product. Hours of fun for my 2 year old. I even bought another for.my nephew and he loved it.
Same as the classic game I played as a child.
The quality is good.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 24 April 2021
Reviews.text: Good action family game for 2yr old to old age players. Youngsters enjoyed practicality but of course needed help with reset. Taught them to take turns and share a good stepping stone to future games. Then they could play on thei own. An old favourite.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 14 August 2013
Reviews.text:
My (just turned) 2 year old and my 4.5 year old love playing this. It's a simple game of chance that's great for teaching younger children about taking turns. I'd say it's suitable from about 18m, depending on how dextrous the child is.
My only gripe is that it doesn't come with spare swords. My son lost 2 swords on the day we bought it (I suspect he posted them down the floorboards grrrrr) and over time a few more have gone missing. It's only £6 on amazon so I've bought a second one to use for spares, but still, shame it doesn't come with a couple of extras.
At £6 I've bought a couple for my birthday party drawer. It'll make a nice present for boys or girls aged 2-4

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 17 May 2021
Reviews.text: I'm very disappointed.. got this for my daughter as I loved it when I was a child and it just doesn't work. We placed the pirate in the middle and put in all the swords (some don't stay in all the way) expecting it to surely pop on the last one.. but nothing. What a shame. Will try to send back.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 31 October 2020
Reviews.text: FIRSTLY THE BOX WAS BADLY DAMAGED .... SECONDLY THIS IS NOT AS ADVERTISED .... I ORDERED A GAME CALLED "POP UP PIRATES" MANUFACTURED BY "TOMY" ...... WHAT I RECEIVED WAS A CHEAPER IMITATION PRODUCT CALLED "BARRELL PIRATE" THAT IS MANUFACTURED BY A CHINESE COMPANY NAMED "HAIZHOU" ....... THIS ITEM WAS SUPPOSED TO BE A GIFT AND I AM VERY DISAPPOINTED THAT IT IS A CHEAP IMITATION AND ALSO THAT THE BOX IS BADLY DAMAGED .... I WOULD SAY DON'T WASTE YOUR MONEY AS YOU ARE NOT GETTING WHAT YOU PAID FOR

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 27 December 2021
Reviews.text:
Bought in October as a Christmas gift. It broke after myself and dad played it once Xmas day. Trigger is permanently stuck down. I had one as a kid and it was durable but this didn't last at all and doesn't seem to work.
Window of return is closed, luckily for seller. There is nothing i can do.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 10 July 2014
Reviews.text: This is a great game, which we recently bought for my youngest daughter's birthday. Both my 3-year-old and 4.5-year-old girls love it. It's so simple to play, I wish we'd got it earlier, as my 3-year-old doesn't always understand the rules to other card and board games that my older daughter has, but all you have to do is take it in turns to put swords in with this, which I reckon she could easily have done from aged 2. It's always a surprise when the pirate finally pops up, and I always shriek because I never expect it to pop up that much. My kids find my theatrical screams an hilarious part of the fun, but they are largely genuine!

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 14 March 2022
Reviews.text: Pop Up Pirate is great gift for a child. I brought it for mine as it was a toy I enjoyed when I was his age. However, the plastic is not solid so it is not particularly sturdy. Great nostalgic toy, just don't expect a lot.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 20 November 2017
Reviews.text:
Great fun for the kids. When the pirate pops he doesn’t half take a good jump. The kit I bought was faulty (didn’t pop) but Amazon had no issues with me returning it and as I was in a rush I went out and bought one locally which was fine.
One star off therefor for potential build quality issues.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 31 July 2022
Reviews.text: Pirate has never popped out since I bought it. Spring function must be broken or not included from factory assembly. Probably just a one off but still rubbish for me.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 6 May 2021
Reviews.text:
My kids played with this 20 years ago and loved it, we had many hours of fun. I bought this for my granddaughter recently and was disappointed at the quality of the product now. It’s not robust, the daggers don’t stick in the barrel and the pirate is difficult to put back in. Needless to say it was returned and a refund issued.
Why ruin and great product and make it cheap and tacky? Cost saving by the manufacturers!

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 26 January 2021
Reviews.text: Good ole pop up pirate! Bought as a Xmas gift. Little boy loves it. Swords are quite sharp once separated from plastic so make sure to file down before using. Other than that its the game we all know and love. Great edition to games night.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 31 December 2019
Reviews.text: As one of the first few family interactive games, my toddler is obsessed with this. Great to learn how to share with others, be patient and above all have fun. This game was part of her Christmas gifts from me and I’m thrilled I bought it. It’s provided plenty of giggles and is the first game she wants to play every day.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 8 July 2018
Reviews.text:
I am 54 and still like this game, although the anticipation of the Pirate popping up can make one feel as if some bodily fluid may escape.
Still well made, a must have for the small people and jolly engaging for us oldies also.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 10 February 2021
Reviews.text:
Two issues with the product:
1. Getting the prirate to stay in the barrel can take a few attempts,
2. Most swords do not stay in the slots and hang out which makes the game less appealing as they will not 'pop the pirate'.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 29 December 2014
Reviews.text:
The idea of the game is to push swords into the barrel and try not to be the one to pop up the pirate. You play until you have a winner, as in the person who doesn't pop up the pirate.
Each time you put the pirate in, the hole, in which the losing sword, is placed to pop up the pirate changes.
Fun game which made eveyone jump each time the pirate popped up. My only fault with it, is it lasts only a few minutes, which is good if your child doesn't have much of an attention span. Mine however got bored of playing the same game over and over.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 21 May 2020
Reviews.text: This game will always remain one of the all-time favourites. It is a game of complete luck and so it makes it fair for all members of the family, whatever their age. I was very happy to have been able to buy this again brand new given that the one I had as a child was starting to look it's age.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 4 March 2019
Reviews.text: Just like it was when i was a kid. We all played xmas day. Lots of swords and well worth the money!

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 27 December 2020
Reviews.text:
Not very impressed with this, the blue swords are thinner than the other three colours, which means they don’t fit in the holes at all! So you can only play it with 3 players, not 4, as they are useless! No good for a family of 4.
I would like to return it for a refund as it’s faulty, but there is no option for a free refund as far as I can tell? I don’t feel that I should pay to return a faulty item. Not happy.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 8 January 2014
Reviews.text: My 3 3/4 year old son is mad for games at the moment so I bought this for Christmas, unfortunately it is very disappointing. He can't load the pirate in so mum or dad have to do it and even then we're not sure it's loaded correctly as there's no clear 'click' - you have to play the whole game and see if he pops… the swords have to be put in exactly straight otherwise he doesn't pop and you only find this at the end after inserting all the swords. He walked away from it and isn't interested which is a shame as the idea is great, it's just badly made.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 20 December 2016
Reviews.text:
Push the pirate in, put swords in the slot and hope it doesn't pop out on your go. Simple design, excellent fun.
Brings back memories of being a child and sitting round with my sisters and parents and wondering when the head was going to pop. Goes up there with a list of games that we love playing with our kids, which also includes Yahtzee, Trivial Pursuit Family Edition, Pictionary and Monopoly.
Also bought it when it was under £7.00 too, so no complaining about that either.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 30 August 2021
Reviews.text: the swords do not fit in securely and just either hang or fall out, the ones in the middle where the barrel has a rim are even worse to try and slot in as the rim prevents the sword being pushed in properly. we pushed all swords in as far as they go but often the pirate does not pop up. this is probably because the swords don't click in properly. expected better from Tomy.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 18 July 2021
Reviews.text: Had this game as a child so brought for my sons birthday! It’s not the same quality as before! The swords don’t even stay in and I used it myself and the pirate didn’t even pop :/ waste of money

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 22 June 2022
Reviews.text: Good laugh for some quick fun with two year to engage the senses but build quality was poor and swords would get stuck and pirate wouldn't pop. Had a few laughs then ended up in the bin when it stopped working.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 5 June 2020
Reviews.text:
I bought this as I remember how fun it was as a child.
The plastic isn’t as strong as I remember, compared and the box was damaged.
But other than that it is obviously just as I remember it and my little one loves waiting for the pirate to pop up!

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 1 April 2021
Reviews.text: Great customer service. The one we ordered did not work, contacted the seller, they posted a replacement straight away and I returned the faulty one. Replacement very quickly and my son hasn't even noticed that we had to exchange it.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 12 February 2013
Reviews.text: (Just) 4-year old grandchild loves this - it's a simple enough game for young children to grasp, sturdy enough for little hands, and there's something compelling about 'popping up' that children either love or hate. However, it doesn't take long for a young child with a little persistance to work out how to make the pirate pop up on demand (simple mechanics!) which rather limits the shelf-life of the game as intended, or requires creative intervention to keep the game in play, which is a little frustrating! This could be easily remedied by the manufacturer and I have written with suggestions.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 12 June 2022

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 7 December 2020

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 10 February 2021
Reviews.text: A great timeless classic, and fun for all the family and all ages! Myself, missus and my 2 daughters love this and it actually makes you jump when it 'pops' so the suspense is funny! Nice little time killer and good fun!!

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 21 February 2021

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 27 February 2021

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 19 May 2022
Reviews.text: Bought for my daughter aged 6, it's a simple but fun game. No batteries required which is a huge bonus, would recommend.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 16 February 2020
Reviews.text: A simple yet fun game that the children all enjoy playing and has kept them entertained. Great that this game doesn't have lots of very small parts as the swords are pretty easy to find after the children have scattered them around the room after playing! The perfect family gift.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 30 January 2012
Reviews.text: This was a simple, fun game for the whole family. It takes next to no setting up, lasts no longer than about three minutes at a time, and the rules can be changed depending on how old the children are. (For us, the winner is the one who pops the pirate up, rather than the loser.) Unlike a lot of children's games this doesn't need batteries, the pieces are big enough not to lose, and it doesn't take hours of fiddling with before you can play. The tension after the first few swords go in is very funny to watch, too. And while I think the idea of playing a stabbing game with your children shouldn't really be this much fun, it turns out it is.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 26 December 2020
Reviews.text:
We have owned this game before for our older children and it was well played with.
I bought this one for my youngest and the quality has really gone down hill.
The ‘daggers’ do not stay in, they flop straight out.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 29 February 2020
Reviews.text: This games was well received by my toddler, who enjoyed playing it with her cousins. Personally I feel the pirate mechanism isn’t as robust or doesn’t pop out enough to surprise the players as much as I would have liked and I found the little plastic knives a bit flimsy.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 6 December 2020

Just like the old pop up pirate, nothing like thses poor remakes of old favourites.
Four year old and his parents playing together having fun just like the 80s again.

Like a lot of other stuff, better left in the past.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 17 November 2008
Reviews.text:
This is a really excellent childrens game. The construction means you have to hold the barrel with one hand while pushing a sword into it with the other hand so you really get a jolt if the pirate pops out. Everyone from Great Grandparents to 3 year olds love it in our family. It's a great game to bring out onto the dinner table after a meal and everyone can join in. It's completely random who wins each time.
It's very funny and the pirate really does jump out a long way.
Highly recommended.

A perfect introduction to turn-taking game play for my pirate mad 2.5 year old, who happily plays with my 4.5 year old without any help from Mum and Dad. I love this game it is one of our favourites, for the following reasons:
- the winner is unpredictable, this means that it is fair and grandparents etc cannot 'let the kids win' so they learn about losing
- it doesn't take too long so you can either slot it in before bedtime when you have promised a game or play it a few times
- it is surprisingly durable and puts up with being bashed about
- it is simple to play so all ages can enjoy it

It's a good activity when you want your little one to sit down and play for a while and helps them to take turns.

Bought this a while now, and daughter still plays with it.

Pretty easy and simple to explain and play with she loves it especially when she wins.
I found out if you twist the base (inside the barrel where the head goes in) you can then change the position of where it pops so no easy guessing.
As other people sugest it really is easy to topple it over, really should have come with a base sucker or more weight put inside, apart from that its good for the price.

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 29 December 2016
Reviews.text: Arrrggghhh be hearties; at last I own Pop Up Pirate! I asked for this year after year as a kid and never received it so thought that I would do what any decent father would do and live out my own childhood through my 3 year old daughter! Well I am glad to say it hasn't changed in 20 years; no it won't stretch your mind like a Sudoko nor will it test your dexteriety like Twister, but if you have little ones, this is a simple game for them to master and most importantly is a lot quieter than Hungry Hippos! Don't hesitate, you know you want it!

Reviews.Date: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on 21 May 2012
Reviews.text:
Pop Up Pirate is a very simple game, which is fun for a few minutes but my 4.5 year old soon gets bored with. It may be better for slightly younger children - it's well made, and quite colourful. Very easy to play, although the very young would need help getting the swords into the barrel. We play a few games where the loser is the one who pops up the pirate (traditional style) and then a few games where the winner is the one who pops up the pirate.
I've not tried it with adults yet, but think that it could possibly make a descent drinking game if the loser has to take a drink when the pirate is 'popped'. All in all, cheap and cheerful fun, but not a long term winner.
